question: Question_04_(b)
statement:
In this question we are once again given 4 points
(\emph{x}\textsubscript{1}, \emph{y}\textsubscript{1}),
(\emph{x}\textsubscript{2}, \emph{y}\textsubscript{2}),
(\emph{x}\textsubscript{3}, \emph{y}\textsubscript{3}) and
(\emph{x}\textsubscript{4}, \emph{y}\textsubscript{4}) in the plane.
This time we want to find a quadratic function
$\displaystyle q(x) = ax^2 + bx + c$ that comes closest to going through
the points by doing a least squares fit.

\textbf{(b)} Suppose the points (\emph{x}\textsubscript{i},
\emph{y}\textsubscript{i}) have been defined in MATLAB/Octave as

\texttt{X1,~...,~X4,~Y1,~...,~Y4.}

Write down the MATLAB/Octave code that plots these points, then computes
\emph{q(x)}, and finally plots \emph{q(x)}.
hints:
Use the matrix \emph{A}, and the vector \emph{b} found in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_04_(a)}{Part
(a)}.

First define \emph{A} and \emph{b} as matrix and vector in MATLAB, then
use to solve the linear system of the least square equation in MATLAB.
From the coefficient vector you can then define the polynomial
\emph{q(x)} and plot as usual.
